Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2012 11:32AM jintski wrote: MJL aren't any mets stage 4? I assumed I was stage 4 even when it was just in my bones. It really is so encouraging to hear some many positive stories, I have had liver mets for just over a year, but have met a lovely lady who has had them for over 8 years, they have been kept stable with a constant dose of capecitabine. Try not to worry to much Mary, my oncologists doesn't even do markers.  I really hope this second chemo does the trick and reduces those liver mets!
Posts.Title: Long term with liver mets? mkkjd60 soleil505

Posts.Content: Feb 2, 2012 08:59AM jintski wrote: Barbara - that is fantastic, encouraging news.  I finished my WBR in early December, but haven't yet had any scans or feedback.  I hope and pray that I do have results like yours.  I had ben worried that I have been having twinges, roughly where the mets were shown to be on the scans, the oncoloist assured me this was the rads still working, but I want concrete proof! Hope you can relax ans stop worrying now. xx
Posts.Title: WBR results banjobanjo banjobanjo

Posts.Content: jintski wrote: Hi I am new to this forum.  I belong to a UK BC forum that has been invaluable in giving me support and information over the past 3 years. I have drawn a blank over accessing information about faslodex.  I googled it and was directed to this forum, I was amazed by the scale compared to what we have in the UK, so decided to ask a few questions. I have had secondary BC since April 2010, extensively in my hip and femur, patches in my ribs, spine, neck and shoulder and a tumour in my chest. Although I am 100% oestrogen + Tamoxifen, Aromasin and Femara have all failed to keep my cancer at bay.  After a progression to my liver in November I have been changed over to Faslodex.  I guess I am wanting stories of people having failed treatments and switching to Faslodex and everything stabilising (or dare I hope... disappearing?) I also would like to hear of possible side effects, are shooting pains a SE?  I have shooting pains in my leg and neck, is this likely to be a side effect of the Faslodex working?  Or is it (as I keep imagining) a more likely sign that it's not working and the cancer is continuing to progress? Thank you for reading this,  SG Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Faslodex information and success stories please? jintski apple

Posts.Content: jintski wrote: Hi Does anyone else experience a strange feeling on the back of their head? I am reluctant to write 'headache', as it feels like the pain is on my scalp rather than inside my head. It started last time I had my faslodex and Zometa and has been almost constant since. I guess I want somebody to tell me it is a side effect of the treatments, as you can imagine I am now trying not to fear the worst! and some recent brain mets diagnoses are putting my brain into overdrive:o( It isn't like a headache more like a prickling on my scalp or a dull throb. My head felt a bit like this when I had chemo, just before I lost my hair! I hope I wasn't given the wrong treatment when I last had Zometa!!! :o) Or does anyone have experience of skull mets that can explain what they feel like, this is actually a possibility, as a know I have cancer at the very top of my neck, so upwards onto the skull is a likely progression I guess. I am a teacher and have considered head lice, but there is no evidence of these little beasts! I am waiting for a full body CT scan appointment to be sent through and have a oncologist appt for the 2nd March, so I don't think it is necessary to phone the hospital. I am just hoping this is something without a sinister explanation. Have a lovely weekend all Jintski Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Strange feeling in the head?? jintski chainsawz

Posts.Title: friggin brain biopsy results :< chainsawz AnacortesGirl

Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2011 06:03AM jintski wrote: hi Ladies Can I join you from the UK please? I am new to this site and new to liver mets.  I was diagnosed with bone mets in quite a few places last April, was changed to Femara from Aromasin (after Tamoxifen).  Then end of Nov 2010 was diagnosed with liver mets. 2 lesions that I know of, but wasn't told the size, only that because they were in 2 different places, surgery wasn't an option!  I was changed to faslodex and as yet have had no appts so don't know whether it is working or not...lots of shooting pains to affected bones sites, don't know if this is a sign of healing or further progression.  Would be interested in how liver mets are treated in the rest of the world. I assumed that I would have chemo, but am trying another hormone, don't know if this would be the case elsewhere, I worry that 3 have failed so far :0( why should faslodex be any different?  Reading some of your comments so far has given me hope.  What I have read on many websites in the UK has hardly instilled me with hope!  Denny hearing of 6 1/2 years is amazing, lets hope the rest of us are reporting figures of 6 1/2 (and above!!!) in the future.  Thank you for giving me back some hope. I will follow this thread with interest if this is OK?  sending you lots of good wishes from England SG
Posts.Title: Liver Ladies jleigh Denny123

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2012 05:50PM jintski wrote: Have you checked out brainmetsbc.org ? If you have brain mets it takes the fear out of them, with clear information about procedures and lots of inspirational stories. I suggest you have a look. I did I bit of research as I was wanting cyberknife, but as I had 4 tumours, WBR was considered the best option for me. Hope you find the information you need,
Posts.Title: Stereostatic Radiosurgery dclark3748 ruthevans41

Posts.Content: Nov 22, 2011 10:05AM jintski wrote: Hi Jelly Glad you are home and it sounds like you are going to be looked after....glad also that there's no more talk about wanting to give up! It is hard to see hope in our situation....but it's always there.  I first came on these boards last week after being diagnosed with brain mets...2 days after you, so I'm relatively new to all this shit too! I was rock bottom and the tears just wouldn't stop flowing!  My flagging hope was restored by all the lovely ladies on these discussion boards!  I have shed odd tears over the last few days, not for myself....but for my son's future. I feel I have now accepted things and start WBR Today, (I have a few scattered mets), I am very apprehensive and dread the SEs, but just want to get in there and get it over with!! The sooner it starts the sooner it gets over with and hopefully I can get on and rebuild my life....brain met free.  Wishing the same for all on here xx
Posts.Title: 6 brain mets for me Jellydonut rosasmommy

Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2012 10:47AM jintski wrote: I had steroids with some of my chemo and wasn't happy on them, so I stopped taking them and was never sick! When I had WBR, it was recommended that I take them to reduce swelling. I decided against them and have been fine, I kept them and would have used them if there'd been a problem, but fortunately I didn't need them. Could you perhaps try one month without, using other anti-sickness meds? then if you have any problems then take them next time? Good Luck and hope all goes OK
Posts.Title: Dexamethosone or not? LouiseBogle LouiseBogle
